L2_gloss:
Suffix meaning many and used to denote a plural.
‎mimini (“woman”) + ‎-ar → ‎miminar (“women”)
A fishing net made with chewed fibre.
separately, standing opposite to each other.

A spear of between 150 and 180 centimetres length and one and one and a half centimetres diameter, made from the reeds that grow on the banks of rivers, lakes and billabongs of southern Australia. Usually used in conjunction with a thyrallghie.
The eastern hare-wallaby, †Lagorchestes leporides, now extinct.
Food derived from an animal, meat.
The ebbing and flowing of the waves on Lake Alexandrina, South Australia.
a fruit with a taste similar to that of an apple.
see you later. The future tense of nakun.
Ruler of Wyerriewarr, Great man of the stars.
sorcery, specifically when disease is inlicted upon the victim.
I; the first person singular emphatic personal pronoun.
pelican, specifically the Australian pelican (Pelecanus conspicillatus), a large water bird with the largest bill in the avian world.
day, the period between dawn and dusk.
wedge-tailed eagle, eaglehawk, (Aquila audax), the largest raptor in Australia.
perch, specifically, the golden perch of the order Perciformes found throughout the Murray/Darling river system in Australia.
Murray cod (Maccullochella peelii peelii), a large freshwater fish found in the Murray-Darling river system.
catfish, specifically that found in the lakes and rivers of the Ngarrindjeri's traditional lands in southern Australia.
the willie wagtail (Rhipidura leucophrys), a common passerine native to Australia, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, the Bismarck Archipelago, and eastern Indonesia.
elected leader of the Ngarrindjeri nation.
fly, in particular the March fly or horse fly
freshwater bream, found in the lakes and rivers of the Ngarrindjeri's traditional lands in southern Australia.
seagull, specifically the silver gull (Chroicocephalus novaehollandiae).
bony bream (Nematalosa erebi); a common, small to medium sized freshwater fish found throughout much of Australia. Under Ngarrindjeri custom, women were forbidden to eat thukeri.
A spearthrower consisting of a long, thin piece of wood with a hooked end to hold the kykie (spear).
ibis, particularly the Glossy Ibis (Plegadis falcinellus).
A camp made of boughs and rushes or reeds.
the seed from a wattle bush.
(botany) reed, specifically the common reed (Phragmites australis).
a hammer stone used to smash seeds.
